ticket.title: select helper breaks for numerical values and displays
ticket.original-body:
If I have builder.select(:method, [1,2,3]) etc, I get <select><option value="1">1</option><option value="2">2</option><option value="3">3</option></select>
This is what I would expect. However if my_instance.method returns 2, the options with value, "2", does not get selected.
However if I do,
builder.select(:method, [1,2,3].collect{|e| [e, "a#{e}"]})
thus appending an 'a' before the value of each element, the behavior works as expected.
I think that the method should match on "2" == "2" and put out selected="selected" and not require an alpha character prefix.
Thanks in advance.
Sam
ticket.latest-body:
If I have builder.select(:method, [1,2,3]) etc, I get <select><option value="1">1</option><option value="2">2</option><option value="3">3</option></select>

However if I do,
builder.select(:method, [1,2,3].collect{|e| [e, "a#{e}"]})
thus appending an 'a' before the value of each element, the behavior works as expected.
I think that the method should match on "2" == "2" and put out selected="selected" and not require an alpha character prefix.
Thanks in advance.
Sam
ticket.original-body-html:
If I have builder.select(:method, [1,2,3]) etc, I get
123

This is what I would expect. However if my_instance.method returns 2, the options with value, "2", does not get selected.

However if I do,

builder.select(:method, [1,2,3].collect{|e| [e, "a#{e}"]})

thus appending an 'a' before the value of each element, the behavior works as expected.

I think that the method should match on "2" == "2" and put out selected="selected" and not require an alpha character prefix.

Thanks in advance.

Sam

123

This is what I would expect. However if my_instance.method returns 2, the options with value, "2", does not get selected.

version.title: select helper breaks for numerical values and displays
select helper breaks for numerical values and displays

version.body:
I can reproduce this. What Sam is saying is that when using the select method in a form_for block and viewing an edit action on a resource, the "selected" option is set if the value for the field is a String but not if it's a Fixnum.
So, if Post.category == 'bar', and the view code is `f.select :category, ['foo', 'bar', 'baz']`, bar will be selected when you edit the post.
But if Post.category == 3, and the view code is `f.select :category, [1,2,3]`, none of the options in the select will be marked 'selected'.
version.body-html:
I can reproduce this. What Sam is saying is that when using the select method in a form_for block and viewing an edit action on a resource, the "selected" option is set if the value for the field is a String but not if it's a Fixnum.

So, if Post.category == 'bar', and the view code is f.select :category, ['foo', 'bar', 'baz'], bar will be selected when you edit the post.

But if Post.category == 3, and the view code is f.select :category, [1,2,3], none of the options in the select will be marked 'selected'.
version.title: select helper breaks for numerical values and displays

version.body: -1 unable to reproduce, maybe a failing test would make some sense into it.
version.body-html: -1 unable to reproduce, maybe a failing test would make some sense into it.
version.title: select helper breaks for numerical values and displays

version.body: @Sam: also, if you use options_for_select([1,2,3], :selected => 2) it's working just fine. besides, it seems like you are trying to create a <select> element that is not related to an ActiveRecord instance attribute, if that's the case... why not code it as plain HTML ?
version.body-html: @Sam: also, if you use options_for_select([1,2,3], :selected => 2) it's working just fine. besides, it seems like you are trying to create a element that is not related to an ActiveRecord instance attribute, if that's the case... why not code it as plain HTML ?

version.title: select helper breaks for numerical values and displays

version.body: >> However if my_instance.method returns 2, the options with value, "2", does not get selected. @sam to clarify, does my_instance.method return a String or a Fixnum? I'm guessing it returns a string, and that's why it doesn't work. You could probably fix it with f.select :category, %w(1 2 3)
version.body-html: However if my_instance.method returns 2, the options with value, "2", does not get selected. @sam to clarify, does my_instance.method return a String or a Fixnum? I'm guessing it returns a string, and that's why it doesn't work. You could probably fix it with f.select :category, %w(1 2 3)
version.title: select helper breaks for numerical values and displays

version.body:
Whoops let me try that again...
<< However if my_instance.method returns 2, the options with value, "2", does not get selected.
@sam to clarify, does my_instance.method return a String or a Fixnum? I'm guessing it returns a string, and that's why it doesn't work. You could probably fix it with
@@@ ruby f.select :category, %w(1 2 3) @@@
version.body-html:
Whoops let me try that again...

<< However if my_instance.method returns 2, the options with value, "2", does not get selected.

@sam to clarify, does my_instance.method return a String or a Fixnum? I'm guessing it returns a string, and that's why it doesn't work. You could probably fix it with

f.select :category, %w(1 2 3)
version.title: select helper breaks for numerical values and displays
